![](/content/media/retina-19-2.webp)

This is the classic OCT appearance for a lamellar hole, which usually has an anvil-shaped (red line), partial thickness foveal defect, with preservation of the outer retinal layers. There is also separation between the inner and outer retinal layers.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: How do you differentiate a lamellar hole from a pseudohole and macular hole?

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-18-3-.webp)

![](/content/media/retina-18-4.webp)

In contrast to a full thickness macular hole (blue line), a lamellar hole does not involve the full thickness of the retina. OCT also allows for differentiation of pseudoholes and lamellar holes, which are often confused for one another as they both lack a full-thickness retinal defect. There is no loss of retinal tissue in pseudoholes, and they have a vertical profile (as highlighted by the yellow line). On the other hand, lamellar holes usually have an anvil-shaped appearance (red line) with loss of inner retinal tissue but preservation of the outer retinal layers.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What is the typical treatment for lamellar holes?

answers.explanation: Lamellar holes rarely benefit from surgical intervention and are typically observed. They usually remain stable, and only very rarely progress to a full thickness macular hole.
